body_text.text: Letter to the 4 COVID-19: Importance of the Awareness of the Clinical 5
As of March 11, 2020, more than 10 500 cases of

BIBREF3.title: 2019 novel coronavirus-important informa-72 tion for clinicians

BIBREF4.title: Characteristics of and important lessons from 73 the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) outbreak in China

BIBREF6.title: COVID-19: Importance of the Awareness of the Clinical Syndrome by Urologists

FIGREF0.text: reported in Italy. On the same day, the disease 8 was deemed to be a pandemic by the World Health 9 Organization, with a warning that health care planning 10 efforts will be needed to face the upcoming spread of 11 COVID-19 worldwide.12 From the experience in Wuhan, China, for 138 hospital-13 ized patients with COVID-19, the most common symptoms 14 at onset of illness are fever (98.6%), fatigue (69.6%), dry 15 cough (59.4%), myalgia (34.8%), and dyspnea (31.2%) [1]. 16 Knowledge of the symptoms and their prevalence is of 17 paramount importance for all physicians, including those 18 from diverse backgrounds such as surgeons, who are called 19 to face COVID-19 disease in their daily practice as well. 20 As far as the urology field is concerned, no certain direct 21 impact of COVID-19 on urogenital tissues has been reported 22 to date [1-4]. However, urologists can be involved in the 23 initial evaluation of patients presenting with fever without 24 other symptoms of COVID-19, often interpreted as urosep-25 sis. The attribution of fever to urinary infection could be 26 supported by the possible presence of urological devices 27 previously positioned to relieve urinary obstruction. 28 Ureteral stenting and the positioning of a nephrostomy 29 tube are common urological procedures overcoming 30 ureteral obstruction from stones or extrinsic compression 31 [5]. Encrustation and super-infections are frequent draw-32 backs of indwelling devices that can lead to the occurrence 33 of sepsis. The severity of urosepsis depends mostly on the 34 host response: elderly patients, diabetics, immunosup-35 pressed individuals, and patients receiving cancer chemo-36 therapy are generally prone to severe presentation [5]. Fever 37 or hypothermia, leukocytosis or leukopenia, tachycardia, 38 and tachypnea are signs of systemic inflammation of 39 possible urological origin[5].

FIGREF1.text: Urology guidelines state that levels can rise during 54 severe generalized infections of bacterial, parasitic, or 55 fungal origin, whereas procalcitonin levels are only 56 moderately or not increased in the case of viral infections 57 [5]. 58 In conclusion, the possible overlap of COVID-19 clinical 59 syndrome with different conditions such as urosepsis 60 should be recognized and deserves proper investigation 61 from the very start of case presentation. The rapid diagnosis 62 and isolation of COVID-19 cases-recognized to be public 63 health interventions that slow the spread [6]-rely on 64 prompt preparation and the knowledge of all physicians to 65 confront this unprecedented pandemic. 66 Conflicts of interest: The authors have nothing to disclose.
